title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: west end stars should give back
story: I BELIEVE Boris Johnson when he says the thing he is looking forward to most as we emerge from our enforced national hibernation is taking in some Shakespeare at the Globe theatre.Butthe Prime Minister is not careful that’s an option that might not be available to him.I’m less of a culture vulture when it comes to high arts, but my heart aches to go to one of my beloved West End musicals. I mean, I’ve only been able to see Dear Evan Hansen  times so far.And Christmas won’t be the same without the uniquely British tradition of the winter panto. How will all those former boyband stars fund their showbiz lestyles for another year Sadly, post-Covid restrictions look particularly cruel to the arts.Those dastardly droplets mean singing is banned and the idea of packing out a historic theatre where the tiny seats mean you are virtually sitting on top of your neighbour just won’t cut it.But in the middle of an international health emergency it’s all too easy to dismiss the importance of stage shows, movies, the TV industry, festivals and concerts.The attitude seems to be: “We’re dying, goddammit, the economy is cratering, don’t talk to me about the bloody theatre!”But that approach will mean Britain is cakewalking into a cultural catastrophe that could wipe off decades of creative progress, end our modern domination of the arts and entertainment and see the closure of most historic theatres before the end of the year.If that is yet another horrid consequence of Covid-, a disease most likely spread because of a despicable Chinese wet market, I will be fuming.Dame Judi Denchs warning that theatres may not open again in her letime is as stark as it is horrying.It would wipe out £.billion of annual ticket sales, see , good folk lose their jobs and damage tourism.While the pressure is building by the day on the Government to launch yet another unprecedented rescue package, I think that’s only part of the answer.Entertainment is a big-money industry dominated by super-wealthy moguls who have a responsibility to look after as many of their loyal staff and young creatives as humanly possible.Now is the time for other celebrities and businesspeople who have earned a small fortune from the creative industries to give back.Where are all those Hollywood stars, with hundreds of millions in the bank, who rush to perform on the West End stage to be seen as a real actor, dahling Surely they could donate a tiny portion of their wealth to set up a private rescue fund for theatres For example, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the South Park creators who are behind The Book Of Mormon, are worth a billion bucks.JK Rowling, whose Harry Potter play The Cursed Child is at the Palace Theatre, has a £million fortune.We Will Rock You producer Robert de Niro has £million in the bank, Sister Act producer and star Whoopi Goldberg £million, and West End favourite Dame Helen Mirren £million.I could name a hundred other multi-millionaire stars who have used the West End to enhance their careers who owe it to the backroom staff on the breadline to be part of the solution.Thankfully, the king of theatre — Lord Lloyd-Webber — has, as ever, proved inspirational and innovative.Without being asked, he is putting his money where his mouth is to PROVE to the Government that it is possible to safely reopen theatres WITHOUT ANY social distancing by using enhanced precautions such as temperature checks on the door and face masks for all audience members.The Government must listen to him and embrace his case study of Phantom Of The Opera, which has remained open in South Korea throughout the pandemic with no issues.Otherwise, we risk the curtain coming down for good.BACKING down so quickly on extending Sunday trading hours was a disappointing move forced by Tory backbenchers.While on first glance the idea of allowing supermarkets and other shops to stay open longer on our day of rest sounds unappealing to many workers, the reality is that this change would have probably saved many jobs in the long run.It’s nonsensical that on one day of the week most Tescos can only open for six hours, while international delivery services such as Amazon continue to decimate their business, especially now with social-distancing measures making it even more unappealing to spend time lining up outside.By contrast, the other night I was able to order an Amazon Prime Now delivery to arrive at my house at pm on a Sunday night.I’d ordered an Uber Eats takeaway from McDonald’s two hours earlier.The archaic current trading hours laws were introduced in , the year Jeff Bezos created a fledgling online book store called Amazon.Like it or not, that business has created a dferent world of consumerism.Compromises to allow workers the option not to take on more Sunday work, leaving the additional hours to those who want to earn extra cash, could make the necessary move more palatable.But let’s not avoid having the debate.THE Culture Secretary has so much on his plate that Shirley Ballas used an innovative approach to attract his attention this week – and it worked.Launching an impassioned plea to Oliver Dowden to “safely open” ballroom dance studios on my talkRADIO Drivetime show, the Strictly Come Dancing judge teased: “If Oliver is out there, I don’t even mind having a cha-cha-cha with him to show him it is possible to social distance.”Clearly the power of the Queen of Latin remains undiminished.Within hours, Oliver had tweeted: “Shirley, as a Strictly fan, I’m happy to talk about how we can get dancing going safely again. Great offer on the cha-cha-cha – I’ll get practising.”Expect dance studios to be back in business imminently, then.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: holidays air bridges july 4 sign off
story: Boris Johnson will meet with First Secretary Dominic Raab and Transport Secretary Grant Shapps to iron out the final plans to allow Brits to go on holiday quarantine free.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIndustry sources expect Brits will be able to start flying abroad from July  and the list is expected to include up to  nations.But those ing will still have to fill out a quarantine ‘landing card’ even though there will be no requirement to self isolate from countries deemed safe.The details will be kept for test and trace purposes, in case of an outbreak on a flight, ferry or train journey from the continent.It’s understood they will sign off on agreements holiday favourites including France, Italy and Spain, as well as other European nations.The aviation industry has been fiercely critical of the quarantine measures introduced on June  and has welcomed the air bridge plans.But the travel industry body Abta urged the Government to set out its plans as soon as possible to allow businesses and customers to plan ahead.An Abta spokesman said: The process of sending people on holiday is not like turning on a tap. As much advance notice as possible from the Government is required for travel companies to restart operations. Greek tourism minister Haris Theoharis said the country wanted British tourists towhen it opens to other European holidaymakers on July .He said: The final decision, from the UK and our point of view, will be in place in the next few days and Im hoping the announcement will be positive from both sides. He told BBC Radio s Today programme there was no need for those ing to the UK from Greece to be quarantined and added: The point is that Greece is a safe country - we have proven that during this crisis and we will continue proving this in the exit stages of the health situation.”The safe travel corridors will be set up after the quarantine review on June  and the Foreign Office will change their travel advice from “against all but essential international travel” to allow travel to these safe nations.France, Spain, Italy, Germany, Austria, Greece, Belgium, Netherlands, Gibraltar, Bermuda, and possibly Portugal will all be announced in the first batch of ‘safe nations.’There will also be a “slow trickle” of updated destinations from then, with medium haul destinations, like Turkey and Dubai added towards August.Long haul flights will be back on the cards from mid to late summer, with trips to Vietnam, Singapore, and Hong Kong given the ok.Officials are also working on an ambitious plan to allow travel from Australia without having to quarantine providing flights have not been in transit in high risk countries.But the USA, Mexico and South American countries are set to be off limits until the end of the year.Dont miss the latest news and figures - and essential advice for you and your family.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out moreGOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jonas blue glastonbury festival 2021
story: But the superstar DJ has revealed there’s a big kink in his plan to play at the iconic venue, as he has OCD which makes him absolutely terried of camping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesI’m celebrating Glasto today on what would have been the first full day of music at the th-anniversary event on Worthy Farm in Somerset.And while this weekend’s festival has been cancelled due to coronavirus, Jonas is raring to get there next June.In an exclusive interview, he said: “I would love to do Glastonbury. Being from the UK, it’s one of those gigs I think everyone wants to do. Hopefully next year.“But no f***ing way am I camping. No way. I’d have to build a house for it to work.“I’ve been to so many festivals with my mates but I’ve not done any camping stuff.“I’ve got the worst OCD so I wouldn’t be camping at all. That’s probably why I don’t have crazy stories from festivals.”Essex-born Jonas, whose real name is Guy James Robin, has cemented himself as one of the biggest names in dance music in the past five years, selling more than million records.Today he’s back with summer anthem Naked, featuring US singer MAX, but it won’t be part of a bigger collection after he decided releasing full albums is no longer for him.Jonas said: “I’m not going to be doing an album any time soon. I really enjoy doing singles. I can move quickly with them, especially in the world that I’m in, because the trends are forever changing.“I’m not planning to saturate the market with loads of records, it’s just about putting Naked out and that being my biggest record to date, I hope.”Jonas hopes the song will be “uplting” for people as we come out of lockdown. But as someone who knows nightclubs better than anyone , he insisted there is no chance they can reopen anytime soon.He explained: “Clubs will not work, how can you tell , drunk people to stand a metre or two metres apart  It’s never going to f***ing work.“It wouldn’t work with meI’d had a few drinks. I wouldn’t even know what two metres is at that point.”SHE is usually a Glasto regular and it’s a good bet you will find her partying into the early hours, but Rita Ora will have to make do with her back garden this weekend.The How To Be Lonely singer shared this photo on Instagram while sunbathing at home in her bra in the scorching temperatures.But she didn’t put as much thought into what she’d be wearing as she would have doneshe was heading to Somerset.She captioned the snap: “Can’t find my bikini.”It must have been a welcome relief for her to get outside though, having spent lockdown working hard on new music.She posted another photo of her home studio, where it was C, and wrote: “Hope you are all having fun outside enjoying the sun, meanwhile we’re cutting vocals with no air con.”Just think about all the tunes you’ll have to perform by the time you hit Worthy Farm next year, Rita.The superstar had said her album would be coming in September but her manager has now confirmed it is being pushed back, partly because the coronavirus crisis prevented her from finishing it.Jonathan Dickins said: “It isn’t coming in September. It’ll be ready when it’s ready.“We’re all in the same boat. You’re doing stuff and then suddenly the world stops.“It’ll come when it’s ready. We have music but we’re still working.”It’s been five years since her third album  was released, while January will mark a decade since her breakthrough record  which sold million copies to become one of the biggest records of all time.If Adele has taught us anything with her music, it’s that it will certainly be worth the wait.LITTLE MIX’s Jesy Nelson probably wouldn’t get very far across Worthy Farm in these shoes.She showed off slippers made to look like her pet pooches on Instagram, amid hopes the girl group could be signed up for next year’s festival.They are expected to have released their sixth album by then and could be a perfect signing for a team eager for more female artists.Jesy said in : “We would love to do Glastonbury, it would be incredible for us to do that. I think we’d be able to get a new audience that maybe we don’t have, people who aren’t too sure about Little Mix. We could prove them wrong, change their mind.”The singer, whose song Blue Jumper is out today, was picked up while supporting the band on tour but almost didn’t get to play for a music boss in the crowd.She said: “I’d gone over a little bit on my set. I was about to do my one hit and the stage director said, ‘You need to finish now’.“The head of Universal had just arrived. Richard ran over and was like, ‘No, let her play another’.”FOO FIGHTERS’ incredible  headline set is among a load of performances stream-ing through iPlayer over the weekend. You can also see Beyonce, David Bowie, Blur, George Ezra, Arctic Monkeys and more.THIS year’s festival was due to be the biggest yet but organiser Emily Eavis has insisted ticket holders are in for a bumper event when it s next year.She said they are hoping to roll over much of this year’s line-up, but had already booked loads of acts for , which may even mean making the festival longer.Emily said: “We’re rolling two festivals together for . We’ve got a hell of a lot of surprises and things that we were planning for the thand we’re going to try to get those things going for next year.“Logistically it’s a little bit complicated because we’d already pencilled in many of the acts for . It was one of those very unusual years where you’re quite far ahead, two years ahead, on the line-up. So we’re trying to work out how much we can fit into next year.“We’ve had lots of amazing letters from people with ideas of how we could make it into like a two-week holiday or run over three weekends. There’s lots of ideas going.”Taylor Swt Kendrick Lamar and Sir Paul McCartney were due to headline this weekend and Emily is hoping they will all be back, especially Beatles legend Paul.She said on BBC  Music: “I really hope he’ll be back next year singing it from the Pyramid and we’ll all be in tears, going, ‘It’s happened, we’re back’.”Me too.SIMON BOYLE - COLDPLAY : THEIR fourth time as headline act and they proved to be one of the greatest ever. CHRIS MARTIN and co won over even the most sceptical festivalgoer and had people in tears with their performance, complete with confetti, light-up bracelets and fireworks.JOE KASPER - DAVE : IT wasn’t just his fantastic performance but meeting his fan Alex Mann, who he got up from the crowd to rap his song Thiago Silva. It was enough to convert workmates I had dragged along to become fans of the Mercury Prize winner and, dare I say, grime.HOWELL DAVIES - LORDE : AT only , she proved to be a cut above when she delivered a standout set, partly from within a huge glass box suspended on stage. The Kiwi’s rousing tracks were lapped up and her visuals included dancers, lasers and clouds of smoke.ELLIE HENMAN - LEWIS CAPALDI : THE moment he swaggered on dressed as Noel Gallagher, I knew this set would be my highlight. At the end he told the massive crowd: “If you haven’t enjoyed it keep it to your f***ing self.” Safe to say, everyone loved it.KESHA has released a tribute to Marc Bolan of T.Rex, who headlined the first Glasto in . She has recorded Chil- dren Of The Revolution, which will feature on the album Angelheaded Hipster: The Songs of Marc Bolan.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cbeebies vet advice post lockdown peaceful pets
story: But for pets that have enjoyed weeks of human company, ato being left home alone may prove more challenging.A whopping  per cent of dog owners say they have bonded more with their mutt during lockdown and are now worried it will experience separation anxiety when they go back to work.Vet Cat Henstridge – known to CBeebies fans as Cat the Vet – tells Laura Stott her advice to ensure the post-lockdown period is peaceful, not painful, for your paw-fect pets.Cats like being alone and won’t be fazed by you going back to work – they’ll probably be glad to see the back of you.But sociable dogs need to readjust slowly to having solo time again.Make an effort once or twice a day to leave them by themselves, initially while you are in a dferent room or the garden.Choose a time when they are relaxed or tired and encourage them into a favourite cosy spot or their bed.If they seem distressed, comfort them, then go away again. Gradually build up time spent apart.Animals have sensitive noses and using pet-specic cleaning products in the home can be helpful to reduce their anxiety.Making sure there are no harsh smells will lower tension levels and allows your pet to relax. .Keep cat litter trays clean, and for very attached pets, especially puppies, leaving something with your scent on, like a T-shirt or old towel, can be soothing.Playing gentle music at a low volume can help to distract from any unfamiliar noises that may worry them.There are even pet podcasts available.Pets who knew le before lockdown should slip back into previous family routines eventually.Cats are already more solitary creatures, and dogs should cope wellyou prepare them properly.However, puppies that have only ever known lockdown, or dogs that have become too used to your company, may find it more challenging.A good way to help them adjust is by pretending to go back to work. Put on office clothes or a school unorm and act out your pre-lockdown morning routines.Go through the motions of leaving for work. Pick up your car keys, settle your pet, then close the door and leave them, evenyou only go and sit in the garden or take a walk.You might feel silly, but this can be really helpful for your pet, especiallythey have only ever seen you in your “off-duty”, stay-home outfits.When you come back in it’s vital that you wait until your pet is calm before greeting them, whether that takes five minutes or five hours.Don’t join in OTT celebrations or encourage reunion “zoomies”, as long- term this can enhance anxious behaviour and increase stress levels.By taking things slowly your pet won’t find the transition back to post-lockdown le too dficult.However,furry friends don’t seem to be settling well and you encounter signs of anxiety, such as toilet issues, high heart rates, constant chewing or scratching, it’s worth seeking advice from a qualied animal behaviourist apbc.org.uk or your vet.A remote camera can give clues to situations you might not be aware of, such as noises, that could be troubling your pet in your absence.With everyone at home constantly during lockdown, our pets may have struggled to rest properly.Cats famously like to snooze but dogs also need up to  hours of sleep a day and may have found lockdown exhausting.Sometimes pets are actually anxious because our constant company means they are over-tired and over-stimulated and now can’t think straight.For all pets it is up to us to ensure they are not disturbed when they are taking time out.Cats are generally good at taking themselves off to cat nap so just leave them to rest, but dogs often need a bit more help to switch off.Don’t fuss over them while they catch some sleep and help children to understand that when their best friend is snoozing, they need to be left in peace.For dogs in particular, lockdown may have changed their exercise routines dramatically, with some getting more frequent or far longer walks than previously.Start to readjust this now, to correlate daily timetables with your regular routines ing.If you normally walk your dog at specic times of the day, such as before and after work, then resume going for walkies on this schedule.Oryou normally use a dog walker or have help from another person during the day, make the effort to introduce them now, especiallyyou have a pet who hasn’t met them yet.If you are one of the many new pet owners who got a puppy or kitten during lockdown you’ve had a lovely honeymoon period to bond with your new buddy.However, it also means it’s likely your pet has never spent any time home alone.Before leaving you new addition solo, you must do sufficient training to ensure your puppy or kitten understands that being separated from you is OK.With puppies, build up slowly to ensure they are happy and get used to the idea of being handled by other people and socialising with other dogs.You can stay with your pupthey are more confident with you around but don’t allow them to be clingy and always reward positive, confident behaviour.For cats, six months is the ideal age to start training with a cat flapyou plan to use one.Professional help with training is now permitted again under government rules and is strongly advised.A bored pet can be an anxious pet. If they are under-stimulated their minds wander and your home can suffer the consequences – so keep them busy.For dogs, toys stuffed with treats, or scattering snacks into their bed to hunt, will give them something to do.There are also tutorials online for making home-made games and toys.For cats, include circuits and teasers to prevent your furniture being damaged.Rotate dferent ones daily, so there is always something new for your pet to investigate and play with.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctors tooth kids nose fell
story: The problem was only discovered when the six-year-old girl, from Xian, China, complained of a pain in her nose and dficulty breathing - but doctors were shocked to find a cm tooth lodged in her nasal cavity. Doctor Qin Xiaowen, a surgeon at the hospital, said: There was a solid object in her nasal cavity. A CT confirmed it to be a tooth measuring  centimetres .“Family members said the child tripped and fell when she was two. She lost one of her teeth, but they never found it and thought it had fallen out somewhere.The stunned doctor added that the impact of the fall had pushed the tooth into her nasal cavity, with only the root of her tooth visible in her nostril and the rest under her skin.The young girl underwent surgery to have the tooth fully removed on nd June, and is now expected to make a full recovery.Wang Yanhui, head of the hospital’s ear, nose and throat department, called the case “exceedingly rare”.A British dentist added that, while such cases are possible, teeth do not grow when lodged in a nasal cavity.They said: It is possible for a tooth to go into the nasal space or maxillary sinusthe trauma is severe. But it wont continue to grow.If it was continuing to grow, then it was most probably the adult tooth. When you sustain an injury to a milktooth, it can have an effect on the development of the adult tooth.The effect is dependent on the age of the trauma.Shown the images he said: It looks like something called dilaceration. Essentially, the direction of the trauma has caused a change in the direction of the development of the adult tooth, so its developed out of the nasal cavity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris bournemouth beach coronavirus second wave
story: The PM warned this afternoon there could be a second spikepeople keep ignoring social distancing rules at Britains beaches.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Johnson said: Let me be very clear about the scenes in Bournemouth - its very important for people to understandyou look at whats happening where in the world where people have been coming out of lockdown.Im afraid what youre also seeing is people taking too many liberties with the guidance, mingling too much, not observing social distancing.Some parts of the world - I wont name them - youve got really serious spikes in the instances of the diseases.The PM said it was crucial Brits dont ignore the rules - which will be further relaxed on July  - warning young people not to think they are invincible. He said: Its crucial people understand that on  July we get this right and we do this in a balanced way and we recognise the risks.You may think youre not going to get it and youre immortal and invincible and so on. And very likely thats true, particularlyyoure a young person.But the bug you carry can kill elderly people particularly. Its still dangerous. The virus is still out there.Downing Street has suggested the decision to close beaches would be left up to local authorities, after Health Secretary Matt Hancock said they would be closedpeople continued to flout the rules. But the Chairman of the Local Government Associations Community Wellbeing Board said they did not have the resources to deal with the massive crowds. Councillor Ian Hudspeth said: “It is hugely dficult for a council to keep beaches open to the public while also limiting the number of people who visit. Closing beaches in one area may also simply sht the problem where.“Councils and the emergency services cannot be left to manage this issue alone. The Government can help councils by stepping up efforts to educate the public on the specic risks posed by ignoring social distancing in tourist environments.He added that lives depended on people taking personal responsibility for their actions. The Governments Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty has also warned that cases will risepeople dont enjoy the sun sensibly. Professor Whitty wrote on Twitter last night: COVID- circulation has gone down due to the efforts of everyone but is still in general circulation. If we do not follow social distancing guidance then cases will rise again. Naturally people will want to enjoy the sun but we need to do so in a way that is safe for all. Bournemouth MP Tobias Ellwood said beaches should be closedpeople dont behave sensibly.He told the BBC: Yesterdaywas deluged and social distancing went out the window. A major incident was declared, the local authority and indeed the police couldnt cope. The beach should have been closed down or at least shut down to prevent people from entering. Mr Ellwood warned that he would hate to see Bournemouth or any seaside resort be where the second spike is the first to appear. The local authorities needed to be handed out greater powers and resources to shut down and close beachesthey are swamped with people, the MP said.Mr Ellwood added: We need to make sure no beach was like yesterday, those scenes were unacceptable, until there is a vaccine we should not be seeing this. He said it was a perfect storm where people were still furloughed and children were out of classrooms and everyone decided to pile into the beach. When asked about the over-crowding on beaches, a spokesman for Downing Street said: Everyone should be able to enjoy the sunshine, and we understand that people want to enjoy public spaces.But it is important we dont undo the hard work of the British public in reducing the transmission of this virus.It is a matter for local authorities to manage numbers, alongside emergency services and Public Health England.As we saw yesterday they are best placed to make those decisions on a case-by-case basis.We have been clear that should we see case numbers increase we will introduce local lockdowns.Pressed on whether the Government would close beaches, the Number  spokesman said: It is for local authorities to manage numbers.I believe Matt Hancock, when he spoke, was referring to the powers to impose localised lockdowns which we have been clear throughout may need to be the casewe see case numbers rise in a particular area.But the Twitter account for No promptly posted a tweet, warning people to stay socially distanced at Britains beaches. George Eustice, the Environment Secretary, said this morning: Clearly yesterday we had droves of people going to the beach in very large numbers, that was much more dficult. We do have powers to put in place closures should that be necessary.If it were necessary to do that to control the virus, then we would. We have the powers to do itneeded, just as we had the powers to do the lockdown. Shocking pictures of the aftermath of the crowds show the beach had been trashed with tins of rubbish, beer cans and glass bottles.Local authority staff were hard at work this morning trying to clean up the beach. When asked about the worrying scenes, a spokesman for the PM said: What I would say is that the PM and the Governments scientic and medical advisers have stressed the great importance of the public continuing to adhere to social distancing advice. Its only because of the publics hard work that weve been able to bring the virus under control.“If the rules don’t continue to be followed and the virus starts to spread exponentially again, then we will look at having to reverse some of the easements that we’ve put into place.And I dont think anyone in the British public would want for that to happen.When announcing that most of the lockdown measures would be lted next Saturday, Boris Johnson repeatedly stressed he would not hesitate to bring in local or national lockdowns in necessary. The fears over a second wave of coronavirus comes after The Sun revealed MPs have been worried about the risk of transmission on beaches for weeks. People blatantly disregarded social distancing rules over night as well, at illegal rave parties in London. title: sky news presenter moon bournemouth beach
story: Sam Holder was presenting while walking along the beach last night after Bournemouth declared a major incident yesterday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAt the start of his piece as Sam describes the chaotic scenes of the day, a man in a yellow shirt and red hat gets into the frame and starts dancing.He follows the presenter for a few seconds before the camera pans away from him. Then in the next shot another man jumps into the frame behind the presenter with his shorts around his thighs and showing his bare bottom.The camera person quickly moves Sam out of the frame to avoid broadcasting the half-naked mans behind on national television any longer. In the final moments of Sams piece, more rowdy beachgoers dance in the background and make noise.The news anchor quickly apologised to viewers over the alarming scenes.In Bournemouth, roads leading to the coast were gridlocked, cars were dumped at the roadside and tons of litter was left strewn across the popular resort.Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole council said it had no choice but to declare a major incident and condemned the behaviour of crowds, some of whom got involved in fights.But beach-goers still left their rubbish behind, with waste collections including deck chairs, bins and boxes of food.Speaking from Bournemouth beach this morning, local MP Tobias Ellwood told BBC Breakfast: This place was deluged and social distancing went out the window and thats why a major incident was declared, because the local authority and indeed the police couldnt cope.We need to learn from this and recognise thatwere going to be serious about tackling this pandemic then we need to be swter in being able to provide support to local authorities who are unable to cope.Seagulls in Bournemouth were seen surrounding the litter as they scavenged for left over spoils.On Thursday morning, Bournemouth beach teams collected  tonnes of rubbish from the stretch of coastline- and the figures are likely to have been similar today.Meanwhile, Heath Secretary Matt Hancock threatened to shut the beaches.In an interview with TalkRadio, Mr Hancock said: We do have that power [to close beaches]. I am reluctant to use it because people have had a pretty tough lockdown and I want everybody to enjoy the sunshine.But the key is to do it with respect for the rules – stay with your household, stay a good distance from other households.But he added thatthere was a spike in the number of coronavirus cases then we will take action.Dont miss the latest news and figures - and essential advice for you and your family.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out moreOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Ditinho do Asilo, who is a member of a Christian party, pulled out the knickers that were sent to him in the post during the call where he thought the camera was off.The bizarre incident occurred during an online meeting of the Braganca Paulista Town Council, a town in the southeastern Brazilian state of Sao Paulo.The meeting was set up for the politicians to discuss chopping down trees in the area.In the video, the politicians can be seen discussing the issue when council member Ditinho do Asilo of the Social Christian Party pulls out a pair of small red knickers.He studies the knickers in depth before lting the thong up to his nose and taking a snf.The politician has tried to explain his bizarre behaviour, saying he had received a present in the mail during the session and had deactivated his microphone when he collected it.He said he was then checking to see what he had been given, thinking that his video had also been deactivated along with his microphone.Another council member tried to alert him, and only then did he realise his camera was still on.Asilo added: “It was a misfortune of my lack of practice with this technology. I wore a pink shirt and, as a joke, a friend sent me these knickers. It was an edible item from one of those sex shops. That’s why I snfed it. I have a family.“It was just a joke that, because of my naivety, became public.”He added that he did not mean to disrespect fellow councillor Fabiana Alessandri, adding: “I agree that it wasn’t the moment to do this, but I wasn’t speaking, I was following the agenda.“When a councillor is at home, they can be doing anything when they join a session and I went to open the package and I was caught.”The council are looking into the incident and have not yet decidedany measures will be taken, according to reports.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pakistan jet runway pilots forgot wheels down covid
story: Sparks were seen spewing out from under the Airbus A as it skidded along the runway at Karachi airport following the blunder by the crew, who were distracted talking about the coronavirus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe plane managed to get airborne again but ploughed into a residential area killing a total of  people in the May  disaster.A preliminary investigation by the authorities in Pakistan has found the pilots attempted to lower the landing-gear during their first approach to Karachi.But they raised the gear lever again during the descent during the flight from Lahore, Flight Global reports.“The landing was undertaken with landing-gears retracted. The aircraft touched the runway surface on its engines,” the inquiry found.In the wake of the crash Pakistan’s aviation minister Ghulam Sarwar Khan said that human error on the part of the pilot and co-pilot as well as air traffic control caused the plane crash.The pilot and co-pilot were not focused and throughout they were having a conversation about corona.The [virus] was on their minds. Their families were affected and they were having a discussion about it.Civil Aviation Authority of Pakistan report catalogues a series of blunders made by the crew.Data from the flight recorders shows that the landing gear was selected as “down” during part of the planes descent.But later when the plane was much nearer to the ground the landing gear lever was selected as “up”. The reasons for this ‘gear up’ selection have not been determined cockpit-voice recordings reveal warnings that the landing-gear was not down were “disregarded”, says the inquiry.Air traffic controllers also failed to notice the wheels weren’t down.When the crew realised what had happened the pilots initially applied reverse-thrust and braking, as the engines scraped along the runway.They were unable to halt the plane to perform a ‘go around’ and take off as they belatedly put the landing gear down.The A initially climbed away, with its crew planning to make another approach but engines “failed one by one”, says the inquiry.The aircraft came down in a built-up area about ,m from the runway threshold.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: archbishop canterbury justin welby jesus statues black lives matter
story: Justin Welby admitted the way Western Christians see Jesus should be reconsidered in the wake of the Black Lives Matter movement to reflect the Messiah’s “universality”.The Church of England head stressed Britains Christian history did not need to be thrown out - but said the context of artefacts, including Westminster Abbey statues, should be looked at.Rev Welby told the BBCs Today programme: “Jesus is portrayed in as many ways as there are cultures, languages and understandings.“And I dont think that throwing out everything weve got in the past is the way to do it but I do think saying thats not the Jesus who exists, thats not who we worship, it is a reminder of the universality of the God who became fully human.”Rev Welby defended images of Jesus as northern European but said it was now common in Anglican churches worldwide to depict him as sharing worshippers ethnicity.You go into their churches and you dont see a white Jesus. You see a black Jesus, or a Chinese Jesus, or a Middle Eastern Jesus - which of course is the most accurate - or a Fijian Jesus, he said.His points were made in response to being askedthe “way the Western church portrays Jesus needs to be thought about again”.The clergyman told how monuments across the CofE, including Canterbury Cathedral, were being looked at “very carefully” to seethey all “should be there”. Rev Welby urged campaigners to show forgiveness for the “trespasses” of people immortalised in the form of statues, rather than tearing them down. He said: “We can only do thatweve got justice, which means the statue needs to be put in context. Some will have to come down.”He added: “Some names will have to change. I mean, the church, goodness me, you know, you just go around Canterbury Cathedral, theres monuments everywhere, or Westminster Abbey, and were looking at all that, and some will have to come down.“But yes, there can be forgiveness, I hope and pray as we come together, but onlytheres justice.“If we change the way we behave now, and say this was then and we learned from that, and change how were going to be in the future, internationally, as well.”Rev Welby said: “Were going to be looking very carefully and putting them in context and seeingthey all should be there.”He said it is “what people do at times like this,” adding: And its a good thing, but there has to be, for forgiveness, there has to be this turning round, this conversion, the Pope called it.“The change of heart that says we learned from them not to be like that, and to change the way we are in the future.”Dozens of sculptures line the walls of the magnicent Cathedral in Canterbury, ranging from William, Duke of Normandy to Queen Elizabeth II.It is unclear which statues will be reviewed, and Lambeth Palace did not immediately respond to request for clarication.In , retired medical artist Richard Neave recreated the face of Jesus by studying Semite skulls using modern-day forensic techniques.His portrait shows the Son of God may have had a wide face, dark eyes, a bushy beard and short curly hair, as well as a tanned complexion.These features would likely have been typical of Middle Eastern Jews in the Galilee area of northern Israel.Dr Neave stressed the portrait was that of an adult man living at the same time, in the same place as Jesus.The absence of a physical description of Jesus in the Bible has left his appearance open to suggestion with Caucasian men dominating likenesses of him in Western culture.The earliest depictions showed him as a typical Roman man, wearing a tunic with short hair and no beard - with his facial hair first said to have made an appearance in AD.Medieval art in Europe typically showed him with brown hair and pale skin - an image strengthened during the Renaissance, by works including Leonardo da Vinci The Last Supper painting.In  white American Ted Neeley played the Messiah in the film version of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s Jesus Christ Superstar musical.In  white Brit Robert Powell played the lead role in TV show Jesus of Nazareth before American Jim Cavaziel played the figure in The Passion of the Christ.Jesus has also been depicted as Latino or an Aboriginal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: footage miserable elephants cruelly tourists
story: The disturbing footage has been shared by the World Animal Protection to show the cruel training process involved in making elephants “perform” for tourists.The inhumane process, also known as “the crush”, is used to make elephants submissive enough to dance on command and take tourists on rides.The footage showed common practices used on elephants including the use of the bull-hook which is a sharp metal tool used to stab the animal in sensitive areas such as the top of the head.Other practices performed include the use of chains to restrain them and frequent exposure to stressful situations.The footage also shows baby elephants being taken from their mother at a young age, tied to a wooden structure and beaten repeatedly. Eight young elephants were seen to be taken forcibly from their mothers, tied up and beaten - sometimes along busy roads.The baby elephants experience both physical and psychological trauma as they get beaten. The global animal welfare organisation is calling for all tourists to avoid captive elephant venues that offer these forms of interactions when tourism resumes post-coronavirus.“We are calling on the travel industry to revise their wildle policies and stop offering exploitative experiences to their customers,” Ben Pearson, Head of Campaigns at World Animal Protection, Australia said. “Elephant riding and other interactions, like shows and bathing, support acute animal cruelty.“We want to expose the true suffering elephants endure for a letime just so travellers can have their ‘once in a letime’ holiday experience.”Mr Pearson said that once travel opens up again, tourists should avoid such practices.“Tourism has come to a halt, but it will re-build, and this is the ideal opportunity to create a responsible and resilient future for wild animals,” he said. Another video released by the World Animal Protection shows three emaciated elephants that are forced to dance on their hind legs in front of a crowd of tourists.One elephant was forced to lt a tourist up with its trunk while visibly wincing in agony.It is tourists demands for such acts of “entertainment” that drives up the number of captive elephants in Asian countries. There are approximately , captive elephants that have undergone cruel training in Thailand alone.As a sustainable, long-term solution, World Animal Protection is advocating for a captive breeding ban on elephants to ensure future generations are spared this trauma.Elephant-friendly venues work on an observation-only model, not allowing direct interaction between elephants and tourists, but still providing jobs and a valuable income to local people such as elephant keepers, also known as mahouts.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: secret letter from prince charles helped us cope
story: The author is the future King, the recipient a retired factory worker from East Yorkshire.Yet, as these powerful words from Prince Charles lay bare, they are connected by the same tragedy — losing a loved one to terror.This newly revealed letter was sent by Charles to Rita Wilkinson, days after her husband Bruce, , died in the Tunisia terror atrocity.It is shared this week — on the fth anniversary of the attack — by Bruce’s daughter Julie Grubb, who says the “amazing” support from Charles and Camilla helped the family to cope.Julie also fears that the  tragedy, which left  Brits dead, could happen again.She says: “My father went on holiday and never came home. I’m worried the Government are taking their eye off the ball when it comes to the terror threat.“My message to them is, ‘Please do more to ensure no other families ever endure the hell we have’. ”NHS pharmacist Julie, , from Leeds, marked yesterday’s anniversary by releasing a balloon at her father’s grave.The last time she spoke to her dad, a retired power station worker, was Father’s Day in June , when they exchanged texts saying they loved each other.The pensioners, from Goole, East Yorks, who were married  years, had picked the five-star Imperial Marhaba Hotel in Sousse because they had stayed there before and it was close to the beach. They also believed it was safe.Julie says: “Before they flew to Tunisia, Mum and Dad had seen the news about the attack in Tunisia’s Bardo Museum months earlier. But dad had rung the tour operator and been assured it was safe to go.“When we swapped messages on Father’s Day I missed him but I knew they were having the time of their lives.”Five days after sending that message Julie was sitting in a restaurant in Leeds with her sister Sharon, , when a new text from her mum arrived. It said simply: “Ring me ASAP.”She says: “I called and Mum’s voice was shaking. She said, ‘We’ve been attacked. A gunman has been in the hotel and he’s shot your dad dead’.“My brain couldn’t process it. I looked at my sister, who told me my face had gone grey.”Julie ushered her sister outside. “I told her and she collapsed on to a bench,” Julie says. “It was a nice sunny day and people were walking past living their lives — but ours had stopped.”The details of what had unfolded in Tunisia were unimaginable. IS fanatic Seeddine Rezgui, , had stormed the resort in Sousse armed with a Kalashnikov assault rle, picking off victims in a killing spree that lasted almost  minutes.Julie says: “When the attack happened Mum and Dad had been lying by the pool sunbathing. Then, suddenly, they heard a bang.At first they thought someone was letting off fireworks. Then a man at the hotel shouted ‘Run!’ and screamed that a gunman was on the loose.”The couple fled but became separated in the chaos. When Rita got to the lobby, she saw an open door and went inside to take cover.Julie adds: “She could see the gunman through the crack. The sounds of gunfire were getting closer and Mum could hear the bullets.” When the gunfire stopped, Rita went to look for her husband.Julie says: “Mum went down the corridor and could see a body covered with a sheet. Then she saw some flip flops had been placed on top of the sheet and realised they were my dad’s.”Bungling officials made Rita’s ordeal worse when she arrived at the mortuary to identy her husband.Julie explains: “They laid out pictures of everyone that died. Mum had to look through them all until she got to Dad. Those pictures will haunt her for ever.“When Mum got home, and we met her at the airport, it just didn’t seem real. There were no words.”Julie said one of the hardest things was waiting for her dad to be ed home. Bruce, a devoted grandfather, was eventually repatriated around a week later on a flight to RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire. Julie says: “When I saw that big grey plane it was awful. Then, one by one, the coffins were brought off. That sight will live with me for ever.”In the days that followed, Rita, , received her letter from Charles.“Our hearts go out to you more than you can possibly realise,” he wrote. Having lost my beloved Great Uncle, Lord Mountbatten, at the hands of IRA terrorists I can at least understand something of what you are going through.“It is beyond belief that someone could behave in such a brutal, callous and abominable way.”The family later met Charles and Camilla at the National Memorial Arboretum, in Staffs, where a memorial dedicated to British victims of overseas terrorism was unveiled.“Camilla was incredible with my mum,” Julie says. “She told her how deeply shocked she was. Both her and Charles wanted to make sure we’d been getting all the support we needed.”The family also met Prince Harry at a service last year to remember victims of the attack.Julie says: “He told us it was very important we made sure we were getting all the help we required to cope with the loss.”Julie adds: “For a long time there was anger but you eventually have to let go or it consumes you.“But forgiveness is not an option. We don’t speak his name. You don’t think something like that will ever happen to your own family. Losing our father in such a horric way is something we’ll never get over.”Julie says the incident on Saturday in Reading, where three people died, brought the nightmare back to le.“It stopped me in my tracks,” she says.“Those poor people who lost loved ones are now going to start the journey we’ve been on for the past five years. My heart goes out to them.” Julie fears lessons have not been learned from the Tunisia atrocity, adding: “My big fear, as we come out of lockdown, is there could be a move towards encouraging people to go back to places that aren’t safe. People that go over there, in my view are sitting targets.”Five years on from the attacks, Julie is angry that firmer advice wasn’t given to her father about the dangers in Tunisia.She said: “If my dad had been told there was any risk he wouldn’t have gone. He was the best dad any daughter could wish for.”Rezgui was shot dead by police and seven others were sentenced to le in prison last February.But Julie says there are still “unanswered questions”.She said: “Are all those responsible now in prison  I’d also like to knowany of the hotel staff were involved. Were they a part of the plot and are they still out there “I don’t think anything has changed in Tunisia. The hotel has been given a lick of paint and that’s it. They’ve even removed the plaque which was supposed to commemorate the victims.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: students may apply university after results
story: Sixth formers currently apply months before sitting exams with often unreliable predicted grades and face a scramble to find new coursesthey do better or worse than expected.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is planning to let students apply after their results and may even push back the academic year to start in January in a bid to improve social mobility and help disadvantaged schools,reported.Ministers have drawn up a series of models that they believe would benefit disadvantaged young people, who often receive lower predicted grades according to research by social mobility group The Sutton Trust.They include sticking with publishing results in August but moving university start dates to January allowing five months to process actual grades.A second option would move exam results to July but starting university in mid-October giving a -week window to apply.A third would allow early applications but giving no offers until results are released and not changing the timetable.Or the system would carry on as now with a five-week window for the application process and term to start in September.Exam results will still be published in August but universities will start in January meaning they will have five months to process applicationsResults would be published in July and universities would start in mid-October giving a -week window to applyStudents could apply before results but offers will not be made until after grades had been awardedOr the model would remain unchanged with a five-week window for the application process and term to start in SeptemberMinisters also want to give the government more direct oversight for admissions to do away with the complicated system of predicted grades and conditional and unconditional offers.Universities have previously come under fire for dishing out unconditional offers in a bid to lure in more students.Universities UK, which represents vice-chancellors, is holding its own consultation and is most likely to back a move for no offers to be made until after results day with no changes to the academic year.Those analysing the plans suggested starting in January would promote fairness, transparency and a “strong social mobility narrative” while giving institutions time to help students prepare for university le after exams.Advocates for the January start also insisted it would have less negative impact on student mental health.But they said it could leave many restless in summer and autumn, particularly for those disadvantaged students who are likely to need to take paid work in this time.Numerous failed attempts for a post-qualication admission model dating back to  were thwarted by universities and school leaders who consistently opposed the plans.In February, higher education regulation the Office for Students launched its own review of admissions but this was halted because of coronavirus.A Department for Education spokesperson said: title: government resources lockdowns flare ups coronavirus
story: He can hardly blame people for “taking too many liberties” . . . they know our July  “liberation” is days away.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThey are bound to cheat a little on a social distancing limit that’s about to be cut in half. That’s human nature.People are still off work. If the sun’s out they’ll make the most of it. Even some foreign holidays will now be back on. Britain has started to think the war is over. Trouble is, it isn’t quite yet.Yes, most of the figures are happily still on the downward trend. A few, worryingly, have ticked back up.And while Boris has no choice but to reopen as much of the economy as ­possible — the alternative is national ruin — we may well need further local lockdowns to quell new flare-ups.The Government must ensure councils have the resources and powers to impose them rapidly.NOT long ago London Mayor Sadiq Khan blamed rising murders on “massive” Tory police cuts. Now he has announced a huge new cut of his own to the cops’ budget.What a masterstroke of timing it is.The capital is on a kne edge, with police being put to flight by lawless mobs openly defying the lockdown.Met chief Cressida Dick warns in today’s Sun that those responsible will face the full force of the law. But the thugs are laughing in her face.Now, to make ends meet, Mayor Khan intends to strip the Met of £million.We know his funding has been hit by Covid. But he has been as poor at managing London’s finances as his old boss Gordon Brown was with the nation’s.And he will always contrive to blame the Tories anyway, so averse is he to taking any personal responsibility.Look around your city, Mr Khan. This is not the time to slash police resources.LABOUR’S solution to funding the gargantuan Covid bill makes us even more thankful they don’t run the Treasury.New shadow chancellor Anneliese Dodds would just tax the rich more and reverse the Tory cuts to corporation tax. What a surprise! You may recall hearing this idiocy before the last election where it was rejected.Low corporation tax helped attract investment and create millions of jobs over the last decade. title: headteacher suspended said staff sat home doing nothing coronavirus lockdown
story: Pauline Wood, head of Grange Park primary in Sunderland for  years, is being investigated for allegedly bringing the school into disrepute during a radio interview.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesDuring the interview on BBC Radio Newcastle, the interviewer read out text messages from parents worried about the level of support schools in general were offering their kids during the Covid- crisis. One suggested the idea all schools were working hard to help pupils was simply wrong.When asked for her opinion, Ms Wood replied: Yes, some teachers have been in [schools], but many have not been in at any time. Safety is paramount, but dont make out teachers have all been working flat out.She went on to say some teachers were working hard coming up with the most imaginative, amazing things but that others sit at home doing nothing - I wont defend those people. Askedthat included teachers at her school, she said: Yes, I think its time we talked about the elephant in the room.Last week a UCL study found a staggering . million children across the UK were hardly doing any schoolwork at all in lockdown.Nationally, kids are spending on average just . hours a day working – around half of what was previously thought.The schools shutdown is tragically fuelling educational ides, with poor kids and those in the North East losing out most, the researchers said.The BBC interviewer said Ms Woods comments were very refreshing but school governors suspended her after a complaint was made.She was told this raised serious concerns about your professional conduct and judgment...which potentially brings the school into disrepute.Mary Hodgson, chairwoman of the school governors, told Schools Week she could not speak to anyone about personal circumstances as it would be a breach of confidentiality.Ms Wood told the Sun Online: As a head teacher, I think all adults in charge of childrens le chances should be excellent role models, so I give truthful answers, behave with dignity and refuse to be bullied into PC.It is very concerning that a headteacher can be suspended for giving a truthful answer to questions posed by members of the public.Writing on Twitter, she added: As head teachers, our job descriptions say we should hold staff to account. Advice in lockdown is not to do disciplinaries, capabilities or appraisals.My school will have a new Senior Leadership Team in September so I asked the new Chair to listen to my signicant concerns about a minority of staff and my excellent middle leaders presented evidence to her too. story: NewsGreen light for foreign holidays as Boris Johnson relaxes border quarantine rulesBrits going on holiday to low-risk countries wont have to stay indoors when they get back to the UK - but destinations could still quarantine holidaymakers when they arrive unless air bridge deals can be struckShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN News ", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Summer holidays abroad were given the green light tonight as Boris Johnson prepared to lt coronavirus travel curbs to foreign destinations.Families could soon be packing their bags for flights to favourite hotspots such as France, Spain and Greece as quarantine restrictions are lted for people ing from those countries. However, it remains unclear whether British nationals could be forced into self-isolation as they begin their holidays. The UK Government is still in talks with countries in a bid to persuade them not to quarantine UK tourists when they arrive. An official announcement is expected next week when the Prime Minister is expected to confirm deals for “air bridges” or “travel corridors” have been struck with some overseas governments. Britons would be able to begin their trips to those destinations the following week. A traffic light system will decide which nations are safe to travel to, with those classed as green or amber available to holidaymakers. Experts have studied how re coronavirus is within countries, whether the UK can trust their Covid- figures, and whether their infection rates are falling, climbing or flatlining. Britons holidaying in “green” or “amber” countries will not have to self-isolate for  days when they get back. But foreign governments could still look at Britainaposs death toll – the highest in Europe – and decide they want to quarantine arrivals from the UK. The Foreign Office will change its travel advice for certain nations. It has advised against all non-essential travel to anywhere in the world for more than three months.  A Government spokesman said: “Our public health measures at the border were put in place to manage the risk of imported cases and help prevent a second wave of the virus, and will continue to support our fight against coronavirus. “Our new risk-assessment system will enable us to carefully open a number of safe travel routes around the world, giving people the opportunity for a summer holiday abroad and boosting the UK economy through tourism and business. “But we will not hesitate to put on the brakesany risks re-emerge, and this system will enable us to take swt action to re-introduce self-isolation measuresnew outbreaks occur overseas.” The aviation and travel industries have been pleading with ministers to thrash out air bridges with countries where the risk of contracting Covid- is deemed low. Crisis-hit airlines have seen bookings tumble and announced plans for thousands of redundancies. The traffic light system, drawn up by the Joint Biosecurity Centre, come as the Government finishes the first review of its quarantine regime. The controversial scheme was introduced on June  by Home Secretary Priti Patel.  She claimed it would minimise the danger of arrivals from abroad bringing the infection to the UK. But critics said Britain had a higher rate of disease than many of the countries from which people were travelling. They insisted a -day isolation for foreign arrivals should have been introduced at least three months earlier when coronavirus was spreading around the globe. But the Government tonight insisted the quarantine system remained crucial to its hopes of avoiding a second wave of infections. People travelling from countries deemed at red risk of Covid- will still have to self-isolate on their arrival. All people arriving from abroad, including British nationals ing from countries deemed safer, will still have to supply their contact information so health officials can trace themsomeone they have been near, for example on a plane, displays symptoms or tests positive for Covid-.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBournemouth beach was a very dferent picture today than  hours ago as the masses finally heeded the warnings to stay away. Local families and young children had plenty of space to spread out on the sand compared to the chaotic scenes from yesterday when the beach was rammed. It was possible to take a comfortable stroll along the promenade without worrying about social distancing. Ice-cream kiosk workers were left twiddling their thumbs as there were barely any customers to serve. The slightly overcast weather has also helped keep the hordes of day-trippers away.  Roads which were gridlocked yesterday had a steady flow of traffic today and there were plenty of parking spaces available in the resortaposs car parks. Meanwhile, Bournemouth Christchurch and Poole Council revealed over  tonnes of rubbish that had been left strewn across the beach had ben cleared in the last  hours. Jill Beck, , a retired sales administrator from Bournemouth, said: The last couple of days were just madness. The amount of rubbish left was disgusting.   I think a lot of people are just selfish. I live here but I stayed away because there were too many people. Thataposs why Iaposve come down today, as I hoped the weather would keep people away.  The council and police have come under fire for not being prepared for the deluge of visitors on the hottest day of the year and for doing more to stop the influx. Retired English teacher Bryan McGuiness, , who has lived in Bournemouth for  years, said: It was disgusting. Weaposre in the middle of a pandemic yet , people came down - itaposs the height of stupidity. Why didnapost the police put up roadblocks to stop visitors. They surely should have expected it on the hottest day of the year. Iaposm sure weaposll see a surge of coronavirus cases because of it. One local business owner, which didnapost want to be named, said the council should have been better prepared after huge crowds flocked to Bournemouth on the end of May bank holiday. They said declaring a major incident was apospointlessapos as the police didnapost do anything to stop people coming to the beach. They said: The council should definitely have planned for this after what happened at the end of May. They should have blocked the roads and introduced larger fines for parking illegally. A £ fine for parking illegally in a spot which blocks ambulance access is not going to stop someone doing it. Declaring a major incident at pm was absolutely pointless. The police didnapost stop anyone coming on the beach, or remove people. There was no big announcement. There was no contingency plan in place from what I could see. Mark Cribb, who runs the Urban Beach hotel and Urban Reef restaurant in Bournemouth, fears the events of yesterday will put staycationers off from coming this summer. He described the councilaposs decision to declare a major incident as an over-reaction which trigged negative worldwide headlines.  He said: People are being encouraged not to go abroad this year and take a staycation instead and Bournemouth is one of the premier resorts in the country that will capitalise on that. Butyou were sat at home in the Midlands watching the images of people sat on top of each other on the beach surrounded by the police you are probably going to be put off booking a holiday here. You always get pockets of people around Bournemouth Pier in a  metre area but we have  miles of beach here and the rest of it wasnapost crowded yesterday. The council need better inform people that there is plenty of space where when the area around the pier is full. Maybe in the future they can be better prepared by setting up a flexible park and ride facility on the edge of the town at short notice for when a hot weekend is forecast. But for the council to declare a major incident which led to a load of police officers arriving on the beach to deal with a large family having an ice cream I felt was an overreaction. The response was like a nuclear war had been declared. I had relatives in Australia contact me to ask what was happening. David Morley, chairman of the Sandbanks Community Group, said the council should have done more to prepare for the influx after the last extremely busy day they had in May.  He called on the council to put more temporary seasonal resources into things like rubbish collection to prevent the recent scenes happening again. Mr Morley has sent a seven-point plan to the council chief executive outlining what he thinks needs to be put in place. He said: I think the council had their head in the sand, it was inevitable this was going to happen after the last one. They have had four weeks to prepare and they did not use that time well. They underestimated the scale of the task and we have a lot of questions.  What was interesting was once they declared the major incident within an hour the place was flooded with police who quickly got a grip of it - sorted the traffic and got rid of troublemakers. The attitude of all these people who had driven from Birmingham and London and parked illegally was apositaposs a £ fine, so what, thataposs fine for a dayaposs parking at the beach.apos From the moment the council realised itaposs going to be a very busy day - and you can tell in advance by the weather forecast - they have got to have a signicant police presence to control access and use their discretionary powers. They need to close the car park when itaposs full and keep it closed and they should have a tow away policy and aggressively remove any cars parked illegally. Itaposs got to be zero tolerance because as soon as one car parks on double yellow lines they all think they can do it. Yesterday Banks Road had cars parked on both sides of the road all the way down so emergency vehicles could not get through. We want to work with the council but itaposs dficult when they wonapost engage with us. The council said they did a good job yesterday but I think a lot of people at Sandbanks would disagree, it was like a war zone. The misery people went through for almost  hours was unbelievable, it was lawless.

Pauline Wood, head of Grange Park primary in Sunderland, is now under investigation after giving a radio interview in which she made the comments. She told BBC Radio Newcastle that while some teachers had been coming up with the most imaginative, amazing things in terms of teaching remotely - others sit at home doing nothing. Ms Wood said she wonapost defend those people during the interview in which parents had sent in messages about their worries around the level of support children were getting from school. When askedher comments about certain teachers doing nothing applied to her school, she said: Yes, I think itaposs time we talked about the elephant in the room. Schools have been closed to almost all pupils for three months - but the government say all children in England will be back at school by September. Under current rules, every class stays in a bubble of only  pupils - and children are told to stick to social distancing rules. But that is set to change from September, after unions and teachers warned there wasnapost enough space to bring all kids back. In a key sht, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is looking at doubling the size of each bubble to . That plan - which heaposs poised to announce next week - would have a huge effect on social distancing rules.  Current rules already admit children wonapost always stay two metres apart within their own bubble. Because of that, when one child in a bubble tests positive for Covid-, all the others in the bubble must self-isolate for two weeks. So expanding the bubbles to full-sized classes of  would leave a lot of social distancing rules redundant.According to The , it effectively means children will no longer be expected to stay two metres apart - or one metre with mitigation - at all times in the school building.
